Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Situation2: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Story:
I sit at my tiny desk, headset pressing into my ears, the hum of the call center a constant background. My screen flashes with another prospect’s number, and I force a smile into my voice. “Hello, this is Anna from BrightConnect. How can I help you today?” The man on the other end immediately launches into a barrage of technical questions about our new service—questions my script only half answers. My supervisor expects me to handle every objection smoothly, to never let a customer feel uncertain. I scramble for the right words, feeling my confidence slip.

Just then, my phone buzzes with a text from Mom: “Can you call when you’re free? Dad seems down today.” My heart twists. I’m supposed to check in, to be the daughter who notices when things aren’t right at home, who asks if everything is okay. But I can’t step away; I can’t let my team down or risk a bad call review. My mind races, torn between the voice in my ear demanding answers and the quiet plea from home. I grip the phone tighter, caught between two worlds, unsure which one needs me more right now.
